content:
It sounds like you're all set for a fun birding adventure at the nature reserve next weekend! I'm glad to hear that you're excited to spot some new birds. And congratulations on spotting those Canada Geese and Killdeer at the local park with Sarah on March 10th - that's a great start to the season!

Remember to bring your field guide, binoculars, and spotting scope (if you have one) to help you identify any new birds you might see. Take your time, move quietly, and keep an eye out for any movement or activity in the trees and underbrush. Don't hesitate to ask for help or guidance from park rangers or more experienced birders if you need it.

Also, keep in mind that spring is a great time to spot many bird species as they return from their wintering grounds or migrate through the area. You might be surprised at the variety of birds you can see, even in a relatively small area like a nature reserve.

If you're looking for some inspiration, you could try checking out eBird or other online birding resources to see what species have been spotted recently in your area. This can give you an idea of what to look out for and help you plan your trip.

Most importantly, have fun and enjoy the experience! Birding is all about appreciating nature and the beauty of the natural world, so be sure to take in your surroundings and soak up the atmosphere.

Good luck, and I hope you have a fantastic time at the nature reserve next weekend!
